meta.content: We demonstrate a low threading dislocation density (TDD) and smooth surface InAs layer epitaxially grown on Si by suppressing phase separation of InxAl1−xAs (x = 0 to 1) graded buffer and by insert...

We demonstrate a low threading dislocation density (TDD) and smooth surface InAs layer epitaxially grown on Si by suppressing phase separation of InxAl1−xAs (x = 0 to 1) graded buffer and by insert...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: We demonstrate a low threading dislocation density (TDD) and smooth surface InAs layer epitaxially grown on Si by suppressing phase separation of InxAl1−xAs (x = 0 to 1) graded buffer and by inserting a tensile-strained In0.95Al0.05As dislocation filter layer. While keeping the total III–V layer below 2.7 μm to avoid thermal cracks, we have achieved a sixfold reduction of TDD in InAs on Si compared to the unoptimized structure. We found a strong correlation between the metamorphic InAs surface roughness and TDD as a function of InxAl1−xAs buffer thickness. An optimal thickness of 175 nm was obtained where both phase separation and 3D islanding growth were suppressed. Moreover, a tensile-strained In0.95Al0.05As dislocation filter layer and high growth temperature of the InAs cap layer further assisted the dislocation reduction process, which led to a TDD to 1.37 × 108 cm−2. Finally, an InAs p-i-n photodetector grown on the optimized InAs/Si template confirmed its high quality by showing an improved responsivity from 0.16 to 0.32 A/W at a 2 μm wavelength.
meta.name: citation_abstract

head.title: Optimized InAlAs graded buffer and tensile-strained dislocation filter layer for high quality InAs photodetector grown on Si: Applied Physics Letters: Vol 117, No 26

div.div:
We demonstrate a low threading dislocation density (TDD) and smooth surface InAs layer epitaxially grown on Si by suppressing phase separation of In
x
Al
1−x
As (x = 0 to 1) graded buffer and by inserting a tensile-strained In
0.95
Al
0.05
As dislocation filter layer. While keeping the total III–V layer below 2.7
μ
m to avoid thermal cracks, we have achieved a sixfold reduction of TDD in InAs on Si compared to the unoptimized structure. We found a strong correlation between the metamorphic InAs surface roughness and TDD as a function of In
x
Al
1−x
As buffer thickness. An optimal thickness of 175 nm was obtained where both phase separation and 3D islanding growth were suppressed. Moreover, a tensile-strained In
0.95
Al
0.05
As dislocation filter layer and high growth temperature of the InAs cap layer further assisted the dislocation reduction process, which led to a TDD to 1.37 × 10
8
cm
−2
. Finally, an InAs
p-i-n
photodetector grown on the optimized InAs/Si template confirmed its high quality by showing an improved responsivity from 0.16 to 0.32 A/W at a 2
μ
m wavelength.

InAs is a low bandgap (E
g
= 0.36 eV) material suitable for mid-infrared optoelectronic devices.
1,2
1. P. J. Ker, A. R. J. Marshall, A. B. Krysa, J. P. R. David, and C. H. Tan, IEEE J. Quantum Electron.
47
(8), 1123 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1109/JQE.2011.2159194
2. Z. Loghmari, M. Bahriz, A. Meguekam, R. Teissier, and A. N. Baranov, Electron Lett.
55
(3), 144 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1049/el.2018.6413
InAs is also well known for its very high electron mobility, more than ∼30 000 cm
2
/V-s at room temperature, and has been studied for high electron mobility transistors.
3,4
3. L. Desplanque, D. Vignaud, and X. Wallart, J. Cryst. Growth
301–302
, 194 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2006.11.229
4. A. Konar, J. Mathew, K. Nayak, M. Bajaj, R. K. Pandey, S. Dhara, K. V. R. M. Murali, and M. M. Deshmukh, Nano Lett.
15
(3), 1684 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1021/nl5043165
Due to these useful material properties, heteroepitaxial growth of InAs-based optoelectronic devices on more readily available GaAs or InP wafers has been reported by multiple groups.
5–7
5. R. A. A. Kubiak, E. H. C. Parker, S. Newstead, and J. J. Harris, Appl. Phys. A
35
(1), 61 (1984).
https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00620301
6. A. Trampert, E. Tournie, and K. H. Ploog, J. Cryst. Growth
146
(1–4), 368 (1995).
https://doi.org/10.1016/0022-0248(94)00535-4
7. H. M. Wang, Y. P. Zeng, L. Pan, H. W. Zhou, Z. P. Zhu, and M. Y. Kong, Mater Res. Soc. Symp. Proc.
523
, 231 (1998).
https://doi.org/10.1557/PROC-523-231
While InAs growth on such wafers showed encouraging results,
8
8. W. Dobbelaere, J. Deboeck, P. Heremans, R. Mertens, G. Borghs, W. Luyten, and J. Vanlanduyt, Appl. Phys. Lett.
60
(7), 868 (1992).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.106490
studies have mostly shown analysis of structural properties such as surface morphology and film tilts.
9,10
9. S. S. Kang, D. M. Geum, K. Kwak, J. H. Kang, C. H. Shim, H. Hyun, S. H. Kim, W. J. Choi, S. H. Choi, M. C. Park, and J. D. Song, Sci. Rep.
9
, 12875 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-49300-z
10. D. Lee, M. S. Park, Z. Tang, H. Luo, R. Beresford, and C. R. Wie, J. Appl. Phys.
101
(6), 063523 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2711815

InAs growth on Si is more desirable because Si wafers are cheaper, larger, and more robust than III–V wafers. Recently, InAs
p-i-n
photodetectors (PDs) and InAs-based quantum cascade lasers monolithically grown on Si have been demonstrated by Loghmari
et al.
and Khai
et al.
11–13
11. L. W. Khai, T. K. Hua, D. S. Li, S. Wicaksono, and Y. S. Fatt, IEEE Photonic Technol. Lett.
28
(15), 1653 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1109/LPT.2016.2564979
12. Z. Loghmari, J. B. Rodriguez, A. N. Baranov, M. Rio-Calvo, L. Cerutti, A. Meguekam, M. Bahriz, R. Teissier, and E. Tournie, APL Photonics
5
(4), 041302 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0002376
13. W. K. Loke, K. H. Tan, S. Wicaksono, and S. F. Yoon, MRS Commun.
8
(3), 1085 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1557/mrc.2018.152
Such devices showed somewhat compromised performance primarily due to the existence of a high threading dislocation density (TDD) that arises from the III–V and Si hetero-epitaxy.
14
14. D. Jung, R. Herrick, J. Norman, K. Turnlund, C. Jan, K. Y. Feng, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, Appl. Phys. Lett.
112
(15), 153507 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5026147
More recently, Nguyen
et al.
reported mid-infrared photodetectors grown on an InAs/Si template by using a low growth temperature technique for full CMOS-compatible integration.
15
15. B. M. Nguyen, Y. Cao, A. J. Williams, D. E. Carrasco, J. R. Jenkins, R. Li, T. J. De Lyon, S. Bui, B. Z. Nosho, and R. D. Rajavel, Proc. SPIE
10624
, 106240Z (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.2306196
So far, compared to the case of GaAs growth on Si,
16–18
16. D. Jung, P. G. Callahan, B. Shin, K. Mukherjee, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, J. Appl. Phys.
122
(22), 225703 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001360
17. P. G. Callahan, B. B. Haidet, D. Jung, G. G. E. Seward, and K. Mukherjee, Phys. Rev. Mater.
2
(8), 081601(R) (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevMaterials.2.081601
18. B. Shi, L. Wang, A. A. Taylor, S. S. Brunelli, H. W. Zhao, B. W. Song, and J. Klamkin, Appl. Phys. Lett.
114
(17), 172102 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5090437
little has been made to effectively diminishing or even quantitatively assessing TDDs in InAs on Si. Therefore, dislocation engineering is necessary to realize high performance and reliable InAs mid-infrared optoelectronic devices monolithically integrated onto Si.

In order to decrease TDD, various growth techniques and epitaxial structures such as thermal cycle annealing (TCA), compressive strain super-lattice layers (SLSs), and single-insertion layer (SIL) have been introduced for GaAs/Si heteroepitaxy.
16–18
16. D. Jung, P. G. Callahan, B. Shin, K. Mukherjee, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, J. Appl. Phys.
122
(22), 225703 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001360
17. P. G. Callahan, B. B. Haidet, D. Jung, G. G. E. Seward, and K. Mukherjee, Phys. Rev. Mater.
2
(8), 081601(R) (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevMaterials.2.081601
18. B. Shi, L. Wang, A. A. Taylor, S. S. Brunelli, H. W. Zhao, B. W. Song, and J. Klamkin, Appl. Phys. Lett.
114
(17), 172102 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5090437
By doing so, TDDs in GaAs were dramatically decreased from 3 × 10
8
to 1 × 10
6
cm
−2
when the total GaAs layer thickness was maintained at ∼3
μ
m.
16
16. D. Jung, P. G. Callahan, B. Shin, K. Mukherjee, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, J. Appl. Phys.
122
(22), 225703 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001360
Using the enhanced GaAs/Si templates, diverse opto-electronic devices have achieved significant strides in performance and reliability improvements.
14,19
14. D. Jung, R. Herrick, J. Norman, K. Turnlund, C. Jan, K. Y. Feng, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, Appl. Phys. Lett.
112
(15), 153507 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5026147
19. S. M. Chen, W. Li, J. Wu, Q. Jiang, M. C. Tang, S. Shutts, S. N. Elliott, A. Sobiesierski, A. J. Seeds, I. Ross, P. M. Smowton, and H. Y. Liu, Nat. Photonics
10
(5), 307 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nphoton.2016.21
In the case of the InAs/Si template, however, two additional challenges need to be properly addressed. The first is to accommodate the exceptionally large lattice mismatch (∼11%), which often results in a very thick III–V layer. However, excessively thick III–V layers (≳7
μ
m) on Si inevitably generate thermal cracks that tend to extend millimeters long. Hence, keeping the III–V buffer layer relatively thin is critical so that a functional device can be grown on top additionally, without generating thermal cracks. Note that typical InAs
p-i-n
PDs are 3–4
μ
m thick. Thus, this restricts the III–V buffer layer to below 3
μ
m on Si. The second issue is the absence of functional dislocation filtering layers (DFLs). For GaAs on Si, In
0.1
Ga
0.9
As/GaAs compressively strained superlattices or single In
0.1
Ga
0.9
As layer were found efficient to glide the dislocations and, therefore, reduce the TDD.
16
16. D. Jung, P. G. Callahan, B. Shin, K. Mukherjee, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, J. Appl. Phys.
122
(22), 225703 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001360
However, no compressive strain material exists relative to the InAs lattice constant without antimonide alloys, and designing a proper DFL remains difficult in metamorphic InAs on Si.

In this work, we report a high quality InAs layer grown on Si via optimized In
x
Al
1−x
As continuously graded buffer and a tensile-strained dislocation filter layer. Both the smooth surface and low threading dislocation density were achieved from 175 nm-thick In
x
Al
1−x
As buffer layers by avoiding In
x
Al
1−x
As phase separation and growth surface roughening. We show a threading dislocation density of 1.37 × 10
8
cm
−2
from an InAs layer on Si with merely ∼2.7
μ
m total III−V layer. Performance of InAs
p-i-n
photodetectors showed a strong dependence on the threading dislocation density of the InAs/Si virtual template.

All samples were grown on p-doped Si (100) substrates with 4°-offcut toward the [110] plane using a Veeco Gen-930 molecular beam epitaxy system. The sample structure is shown schematically in
Fig. 1(a)
. The large lattice mismatch was divided to two sections, from Si to GaAs and to InAs as shown in
Fig. 1(b)
. We first employed two-step growth, four TCA cycles (350–650 °C), and an In
0.1
Ga
0.9
As SIL for the GaAs buffer on Si.
16
16. D. Jung, P. G. Callahan, B. Shin, K. Mukherjee, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, J. Appl. Phys.
122
(22), 225703 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001360
Then, the In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffers were grown with different thicknesses from 70 nm to 700 nm. A relatively low growth temperature of 420 °C was chosen to avoid the strong phase separation issue in the In
x
Al
1−x
As ternary alloy and to achieve a smooth surface morphology. To keep the total III–V layer thickness consistent among the samples, the InAs cap layer thickness varied from 1400 nm to 500 nm and all other growth conditions were kept identical.
Table I
lists all the samples with the structure, growth condition, and characterization results. Electron channeling contrast imaging (ECCI) was used to calculate TDDs using a FEI Inspector-F50 machine equipped with a back-scattered electron detector.

FIG. 1.
(a) Sample structure for InAs on Si using In
x
Al
1−x
As continuously graded buffers. (b) Lattice mismatch as a function of epitaxial layer thickness. Mismatches for In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffers are approximate.

TABLE I.
Summary of InAs on Si templates.

a
Temperature was measured by an optical pyrometer.

b
RMS surface roughness is an average of three 10 × 10
μ
m
2
scans.

Figure 2
summarizes the effect of the In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffer thickness on the surface roughness and TDD. The lowest surface roughness and TDD were both achieved from sample C (thickness = 175 nm), suggesting a strong correlation between surface roughness and TDD during the In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffer growth. Mori
et al.
previously reported that the rough surface induced by the phase separation of the InGaP alloys can limit misfit dislocation glide velocity and, consequently, decrease the efficacy of the dislocation annihilation process.
20
20. M. J. Mori, S. T. Boles, and E. A. Fitzgerald, J. Vac. Sci. Technol., A
28
(2), 182 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1116/1.3290762
To solve this problem, Kohen
et al.
tried using InGaAs interlayers to prevent the phase separation of the In
x
Al
1−x
As (x = 0–0.52) buffers on Si for growth of an InP virtual substrate,
21
21. D. Kohen, X. S. Nguyen, R. I. Made, C. Heidelberger, K. H. Lee, K. E. K. Lee, and E. A. Fitzgerald, J. Cryst. Growth
478
, 64 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2017.08.025
but the cap layer showed a very rough surface morphology of root mean square (RMS) roughness > 9 nm, which is still indicative of the presence of phase separation. This led to a TDD of 1 × 10
8
cm
−2
for the InP layer on Si. In contrast, growing very thin In
x
Al
1−x
As buffers to avoid phase separation was considered, but we found this led to severe surface roughening via 3D islanding growth because of the high lattice mismatch. As a result, this has escalated the TDD as seen in sample D. Therefore, the optimal thickness was determined in between the two different growth regimes where both the smooth surface morphology (∼2.5 nm) and a low TDD were achieved simultaneously.

FIG. 2.
RMS surface roughness and TDD as a function of In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffer thickness in InAs/Si templates. Roughness is an average of three different 10 × 10
μ
m
2
scans.

We have attempted to decrease the TDD further down by inserting a 200 nm-thick tensile-strained In
0.95
Al
0.05
As layer prior to the InAs cap layer.
Figures 3(a)
and
3(b)
show that the TDD of Sample E was substantially reduced to 2.2 × 10
8
cm
−2
, which is more than a factor of 2 decrease compared to reference Sample C (5.6 × 10
8
cm
−2
). Instead, the surface roughness was slightly increased to 3.18 nm probably because of the slight phase separation in the In
0.95
Al
0.05
As DFL grown at 500 °C. Insertion of a DFL has been a common technique for GaAs on Si because this provides an interface where TDs propagating upward have a chance to glide in order to relax the additional compressive strain and interact with each other for the reduction process.
16,22
16. D. Jung, P. G. Callahan, B. Shin, K. Mukherjee, A. C. Gossard, and J. E. Bowers, J. Appl. Phys.
122
(22), 225703 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001360
22. G. E. Beltz, M. Chang, J. S. Speck, W. Pompe, and A. E. Romanov, Philos. Mag. A
76
(4), 807 (1997).
https://doi.org/10.1080/01418619708214212
The reason behind using compressively strained layers as DFL is that the misfit dislocations are glissile and they can glide readily.
23,24
23. J. Narayan and S. Sharan, Mater. Sci. Eng. B
10
(4), 261 (1991).
https://doi.org/10.1016/0921-5107(91)90100-A
24. E. A. Fitzgerald, Mater. Sci. Rep.
7
(3), 87 (1991).
https://doi.org/10.1016/0920-2307(91)90006-9
On the contrary, dislocations through tensile strain relaxation are known to be sessile in nature. This impeded dislocation movement was believed to decrease the efficacy of dislocation annihilation process, and thus the use of the tensile strained layer has been circumvented. However, we observed a factor of 2 decrease in TDD, which is against the previous hypothesis. The underlying mechanism of the tensile-strained In
0.95
Al
0.05
As DFL is not clearly understood yet and needs further investigation.

FIG. 3.
ECCI images of the InAs layer grown on Si via optimized 175 nm In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffers. (a) Sample C
without
tensile-strained DFL and InAs cap grown at 460 °C. (b) Sample E with DFL and InAs cap grown at 460 °C. (c) Sample F with DFL and InAs cap grown at 490 °C.

A higher growth temperature of the metamorphic InAs layer can increase dislocation glide velocity and decrease the TDD.
25
25. E. A. Fitzgerald, A. Y. Kim, M. T. Currie, T. A. Langdo, G. Taraschi, and M. T. Bulsara, Mater. Sci. Eng. B
67
(1–2), 53 (1999).
https://doi.org/10.1016/S0921-5107(99)00209-3
Sample F was grown to study the impact by growing the InAs cap layer at 490 °C, 30 °C higher than sample E.
Figure 3(c)
shows only several TDs and we have achieved a TDD of 1.37 × 10
8
cm
−2
. While we have intentionally lowered the substrate temperature for the In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffer growth to suppress the detrimental phase separation as aforementioned, it makes sense to raise the growth temperature of the InAs cap layer to facilitate the dislocation glide and to lower the TDD in the end. Therefore, we demonstrated a strategy of enhancing dislocation glide velocity while controlling phase separation to obtain a smooth surface and low TDD in metamorphic InAs on Si.

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of
Fig. 4(a)
show evolution of dislocations from the initial GaAs/Si interface all the way to the InAs cap layer. The imaged specimen thickness was maintained at ∼200 nm, and one TD in the 1200 nm-wide image corresponds to a TDD of ∼4 × 10
8
cm
−2
. The AlAs layer seems to show no TDs in the image, but a high density of TDs were generated during the In
x
Al
1−x
As buffer growth. Most of newly nucleated dislocations were contained in the continuously graded In
x
Al
1−x
As buffers. The propagating TDs were mostly filtered out by the tensile-strained DFL, and the InAs cap is free of TDs in the image.
Figure 4(b)
shows periodically placed Lomer dislocations or edge dislocations at the interface between Si and GaAs. Those 90° edge dislocations consist of a pair of 60° misfit dislocations that do not have threading components. The fact that a TDD > 5 × 10
9
cm
2
is observed in the early GaAs buffer suggests that some fraction of the misfit dislocations threaded into the growth direction. The type of the misfit dislocation seen in
Fig. 4(c)
is a clustered 60° misfit dislocation. Many of them were annihilated with each other within the optimized In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffer. Finally, the remaining TDs at a density of ∼5 × 10
8
cm
−2
have propagated toward the tensile-strained In
x
Al
1−x
As DFL, and some of them were recycled to relax the DFL as shown in
Fig. 4(d)
. The tensile strain relaxation should have increased the chance of the TD reduction process by incurring fusion or annihilation as illustrated in
Fig. 4(e)
.

FIG. 4.
Sample F (a) a stitched bright-field TEM image. The inset shows a selected area diffraction pattern of the [220] excitation condition used to boost dislocation contrast. [(b)–(d)] Zoomed-in images at the interface between GaAs and Si, at the In
x
Al
1−x
As graded buffer, and at the In
0.95
Al
0.05
As DFL. The TEM specimen thickness was 200 and 100 nm for (a) and [(b)–(d)], respectively. (e) Schematic illustration of dislocation interactions. (1) Annihilation, (2) fusion, (3) recycle + propagation, and (4) recycle + propagation + recycle.

Three InAs/Si templates, samples A, E, and F, were chosen for growth of InAs
p-i-n
PDs to confirm the impact of TDD on the PD performance. A 200 nm n-type InAs layer was first grown at a concentration of 1 × 10
17
cm
−3
. Then, an unintentionally doped 2000 nm InAs layer was grown, followed by a p-type InAs layer doped at 5 × 10
18
cm
−3
. Samples were fabricated using standard photolithography. The size of the window and mesa was 500
μ
m and 680
μ
m, respectively. The two-top contact scheme was used to avoid the III/V-Si interface. The responsivity of the PDs was tested at 0 V bias (photovoltaic mode) under a 2
μ
m wavelength laser source.
Figure 5(a)
shows dark current densities measured at room temperature. The leakage currents were increased from 1.62 A/cm
2
to 6.30 A/cm
2
at −0.5 V as the TDDs were increased because TDs act as generation and recombination centers in the p-i-n junction.
26
26. L. M. Giovane, H. C. Luan, A. M. Agarwal, and L. C. Kimerling, Appl. Phys. Lett.
78
(4), 541 (2001).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1341230
The inset reveals that the relatively thin total III–V layer thickness, which in this work is about 5.2
μ
m, yielded crack-free InAs PDs. Responsivities are shown in
Fig. 5(b)
as a function of bias voltage from −0.5 V to 0 V at room temperature. A clear trend was observed among the three PDs that the PD with a lower TDD possesses a higher responsivity throughout the measurement span.
Figure 5(c)
summarizes the responsivities at 0 V and the leakage currents measured at −0.5 V as a function of TDD. The PD responsivity was increased from 0.16 A/W to 0.32 A/W as the TDD was decreased in the InAs buffer on Si. The high responsivity is almost comparable to an InAs PD that we grew on an InAs wafer homoepitaxially for comparison, which showed a responsivity of 0.4 A/W (not shown here). Note that a commercial InAs PD from Hamamatsu shows ∼0.6 A/W at 2
μ
m presumably with an anti-reflection coating.
27
27. See
https://www.hamamatsu.com/jp/en/product/type/P7163/index.html
for more information about InAs photodetector specifications in the Hamamatsu Photonics.
Based on the trend between responsivity and TDD in
Fig. 5
, we expect that an InAs/Si template with a TDD of ∼5 × 10
7
cm
−2
is required to match the commercial InAs PD performance. Future work includes the study of the InAs/Si template uniformity and realization of mid-infrared focal plane arrays.
28
28. J. M. Fastenau, D. Lubyshev, S. A. Nelson, M. Kattner, P. Frey, M. Fetters, J. Zeng, A. W. K. Liu, A. O. Morgan, S. A. Edwards, R. Dennis, K. Beech, D. Burrows, K. Patnaude, R. Faska, J. Bundas, A. Reisinger, M. Sundaram, and M. J. Furlong, Infrared Technol. Appl.
XLV. 11002
, 110020M (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.2521055

FIG. 5.
(a) Dark current density curves from PDs grown on various templates. The inset shows four InAs PDs grown on Si. No thermal cracks were observed throughout the wafer. (b) Room-temperature responsivities vs voltage. (c) Responsivities and leakage current of InAs p-i-n PD on Si as a function of threading dislocation density. Responsivities were measured from four different PDs from each template in photovoltaic mode (bias= 0 V) using a 2
μ
m wavelength laser.

In summary, we presented high quality InAs buffer layer growth on Si with a total III–V layer thickness less than 2.7
μ
m. A smooth surface morphology and low threading dislocation density were achieved by finding an optimal In
x
Al
1−x
As continuously graded buffer thickness, where both phase separation and 3D islanding growth were inhibited. A tensile-strained dislocation filter layer further reduced the dislocation density by more than a factor of 2. Thermal crack-free InAs
p-i-n
photodetectors confirmed highly improved crystal quality by showing increased responsivity and reduced leakage current. This high quality InAs/Si template can be applied to other opto-electronic devices such as quantum cascade lasers and type-II superlattices for a techno-economic approach.
AUTHORS' CONTRIBUTIONS
Section:
G.R. and S.W. contributed equally to this work.

This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea No. NRF-2017M1A2A2048904, KIST Flagship Project (No. 2E30100), and KIST Incubating program (No. 2V08130). The authors are thankful to Dr. Do Kyung Hwang and Dr. Gyu Weon Hwang for their support in the device measurement. We are also grateful to Dr. Jindong Song and Dr. Gunwoo Ju for project management and MBE maintenance at KIST.
DATA AVAILABILITY
The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
